console_output: [Orchestral]   Lesson 1/10: The Evolution of Version Control
[Orchestral]   Lesson 2/10: The Git Architecture: Under the Hood
[Orchestral]   Lesson 3/10: The Local Workflow: Staging and Committing
[Orchestral]   Lesson 4/10: Branching Strategies and Parallel Development
[Orchestral]   Lesson 7/10: Undoing Changes and Time Travel
[Orchestral]   Lesson 8/10: Advanced Rebase and Interactive Tools

syllabus.course_title: Mastering Git: From Theory to Terminal
syllabus.course_objective: To provide a comprehensive understanding of version control through academic theory, hands-on tutorial application, and professional documentation standards, enabling students to manage source code independently and collaboratively.

lessons.title: The Evolution of Version Control
objectives: Define Version Control Systems (VCS) and their fundamental purpose in software development
Differentiate between Centralized (CVCS) and Distributed (DVCS) models
Explain the historical context of Git's creation and its philosophical shift from SVN
Install Git and perform initial global user configuration
Navigate internal documentation using 'git help' and official manual pages
content_outline: Introduction to VCS: Tracking changes, collaboration, and integrity
The Centralized Era: Understanding Subversion (SVN) and the single-point-of-failure risk
The Distributed Revolution: How Git enables full local history and offline work
The Birth of Git: Linus Torvalds and the BitKeeper controversy (2005)
Philosophical Shift: Snapshots vs. Delta-based storage
Initial Setup: The 'git config' command and the global configuration file
Self-Documentation: Accessing the manual via CLI and web interfaces
activities: Comparative Analysis: Diagramming the workflow of SVN vs. Git in small groups
Guided Installation: Step-by-step setup on Windows (Git Bash), macOS, or Linux
Lab Exercise: Setting 'user.name' and 'user.email' and verifying via '.gitconfig' viewing
Documentation Scavenger Hunt: Using 'git help <command>' to find specific flags for 'git init' and 'git config'
resources: Pro Git Book by Scott Chacon and Ben Straub (Chapters 1.1 - 1.6)
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git. Apress.
Torvalds, L. (2005). Git: A replacement for BitKeeper.
Spinellis, D. (2012). Version Control Systems. IEEE Software, 29(5), 100-101.

lessons.title: The Git Architecture: Under the Hood
objectives: Explain the 'Three States' of Git (Working Directory, Staging Area, and Git Directory)
Understand the Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) structure and how commits are linked
Identify Git's internal data objects: Blobs, Trees, Commits, and Tags
Navigate and explain the purpose of the .git folder structure
content_outline: Introduction to Content-Addressable Storage: Key-value pairs and SHA-1 hashing
The Git Object Model: Blobs (files), Trees (directories), Commits (snapshots), and Tags
The Three States: Working Directory (Modified), Staging Area/Index (Staged), and Git Directory (Committed)
The Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG): How Git tracks history through parent pointers
Exploring the .git directory: HEAD, config, objects/, and refs/
activities: Hands-on: Run 'git init' and use 'ls -a .git' to inspect the initial repository skeleton
Deep Dive: Create a file, use 'git hash-object' to manually generate a blob, and locate it in .git/objects
Visualization: Draw a DAG representing three sequential commits to show parent-child relationships
State Flow: Move a file through the 'Modified -> Staged -> Committed' lifecycle and check status at each step
resources: Pro Git Book, Chapter 10: Git Internals - Git Objects
Visual Studio Code with GitLens extension for object visualization
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git. Apress.
Git Documentation. (n.d.). Git Internals - Plumbing and Porcelain. git-scm.com/docs.
Loeliger, J., & McCullough, M. (2012). Version Control with Git. O'Reilly Media.

lessons.title: The Local Workflow: Staging and Committing
objectives: Master the staging area (Index)
Write effective, standardized commit messages
Analyze file changes using diff
content_outline: Introduction to the Three-Tree Architecture: Working Directory, Staging Index, and HEAD
The Theory of Atomic Commits: Why smaller, single-purpose changes improve codebase maintainability
Deep dive into 'git status': Interpreting tracked vs. untracked files
The Staging Mechanism: Selective staging using 'git add' and 'git add -p' (patch mode)
Anatomy of a Commit: Metadata, snapshots (not deltas), and SHA-1 hashes
Standardizing Communication: The Conventional Commits specification and imperative mood
Visualizing Changes: Using 'git diff' to compare the working directory against the index
activities: Interactive Exercise: Create multiple files and use 'git add' to selectively stage only one to observe the difference in 'git status'
Writing Lab: Draft a commit message following the 'Subject/Body/Footer' template for a hypothetical bug fix
Comparison Challenge: Use 'git diff' to identify a specific line change, then use 'git diff --cached' to see changes ready for commit
Clean-up Drill: Use 'git restore --staged' to unstage a file accidentally marked for commit
resources: A sample text repository for modification
Documentation: Pro Git Book, Chapter 2.2 (Recording Changes to the Repository)
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git (2nd ed.). Apress.
Conventional Commits. (n.d.). A specification for adding human and machine readable meaning to commit messages. https://www.conventionalcommits.org/
Torvalds, L., & Hamano, J. (2023). Git Documentation: git-commit(1) and git-add(1) Manual Pages.

lessons.title: Branching Strategies and Parallel Development
objectives: Understand the conceptual 'pointer' nature of branches
Compare Git Flow vs. GitHub Flow
Execute seamless context switching
content_outline: Branching as a low-cost operation: How Git uses 41-byte files to manage pointers to commits.
The Lifecycle of a Branch: Creation, HEAD movement, and deletion.
GitHub Flow: A lightweight, branch-based workflow for continuous deployment.
Git Flow: A robust framework for managing large-scale releases and hotfixes.
Best practices for naming conventions and short-lived feature branches.
activities: Interactive terminal session: Creating a 'feature-login' branch and making isolated commits.
Simulated Context Switch: Using 'git checkout' to jump between two distinct code states without interference.
Branch Cleanup: Identifying merged branches and practicing safe deletion using '-d' vs forced deletion with '-D'.
Group Discussion: Evaluating which branching strategy fits a specific project scenario (Web App vs. Embedded Software).
resources: Article: 'A successful Git branching model' by Vincent Driessen
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git. Apress.
Driessen, V. (2010). A successful Git branching model. nvie.com.
Atlassian Bitbucket. (2023). Git Branching Tutorials and Workflows.

lessons.title: Merging and Conflict Resolution
objectives: Distinguish between Fast-forward and Three-way merges
Identify the anatomy of a merge conflict
Resolve conflicts manually and with tools
content_outline: Introduction to Merging: Integrating changes from different development streams
The Fast-Forward Merge: How Git moves the branch pointer when the history is linear
The Three-Way Merge (Recursive): Creating a merge commit when history has diverged
Conflict Theory: Why overlaps occur when the same lines are edited in different branches
The Anatomy of a Conflict: Understanding Head, the separator (=======), and the incoming change
Manual Resolution: Editing files to remove markers and choosing the final state
The Abort Strategy: Using 'git merge --abort' to return to a pre-merge state
GUI Tools: Brief overview of using VS Code and specialized merge tools
activities: Step-by-step tutorial: Creating a 'feature' branch and performing a clean Fast-forward merge into 'main'
Simulated Conflict: Intentionally editing the same line in two branches to trigger a merge conflict
Hands-on Lab: Reading conflict markers in a text editor and manually resolving them
Practice: Using the 'git status' command during a conflicted state to identify unmerged paths
resources: Command line terminal with Git installed
Text editor (e.g., VS Code, Sublime Text, or Vim)
Sample repository containing a 'README.md' and simple code files
Visual diagrams illustrating branch pointers and merge commits
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git (2nd ed.). Apress.
Git Documentation. (n.d.). git-merge - Join two or more development histories together. https://git-scm.com/docs/git-merge
Atlassian Bitbucket Tutorials. (n.d.). Git Merge Conflicts. https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/using-branches/merge-conflicts

lessons.title: Collaborating with Remotes
objectives: Explain the relationship between Local and Remote repositories
Understand 'Upstream' tracking
Securely connect via SSH and HTTPS
content_outline: Distributed version control architecture: Local vs. Remote storage
The synchronization workflow: Push, Fetch, and Pull mechanics
Security models: HTTPS with Personal Access Tokens (PAT) vs. SSH Key-pairs
Tracking branches and the concept of 'Upstream' (origin/main)
Remote URL management and naming conventions
activities: Generate and configure an SSH key-pair for GitHub/GitLab authentication
Execute 'git remote add origin' to link a local repository to a cloud host
Simulate a collaborative conflict by modifying a file via the web UI and attempting a local 'git push'
Practice 'git fetch' followed by 'git merge' to manually synchronize state before using 'git pull'
resources: Official Git Documentation: Working with Remotes
GitHub Docs: Connecting to GitHub with SSH
Visualizing Git: Remote branch interactive diagrams
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git (2nd ed.). Apress.
Spinellis, D. (2012). Git. IEEE Software, 29(3), 100-101.
GitHub Engineering. (2021). Token authentication requirements for Git operations.

lessons.title: Undoing Changes and Time Travel
objectives: Safely revert mistakes without losing data
Understand the dangers of rewriting history
Use the Reflog for emergency recovery
content_outline: Immutability vs. Historical Editing: The philosophy of the Git directed acyclic graph (DAG).
Dissecting 'git checkout' for file-level restoration (pre-Switch/Restore syntax).
The Revert Method: Creating 'inverse commits' to preserve public audit trails.
The Reset Spectrum: Deep dive into --soft (keep index), --mixed (keep working tree), and --hard (discard all).
The Git Safety Net: Utilizing 'git reflog' to track HEAD movement and recover 'deleted' commits.
Best Practices: When to reset (private branches) vs. when to revert (shared branches).
activities: The 'Undo' Lab: Students will intentionally break a codebase and use git checkout and git reset --hard to restore it.
The Inverse Audit: Students will simulate a production bug fix using git revert to maintain a clean history.
Reflog Rescue: A 'hidden' commit will be deleted via a hard reset, and students must use the reflog to find the hash and restore it.
Reset Level Matrix: Interactive quiz matching scenarios (e.g., 'Forgot to add a file to a commit') to the correct reset flag.
resources: Visualizing Git (Interactive D3 tool for graph visualization)
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git (2nd ed.). Apress. Section 7.7: Git Tools - Rewriting History.
Git Documentation. (n.d.). git-reset(1) Manual Page.
Atlassian Bitbucket Tutorials. (n.d.). Undoing Changes: git checkout, git reset, git revert.

lessons.title: Advanced Rebase and Interactive Tools
objectives: Master the 'Rebase' vs. 'Merge' debate
Perform interactive rebasing to clean history
Squash and fixup commits
content_outline: Philosophy of Project History: Linear vs. Nonlinear workflows
The Golden Rule of Rebasing: Why you never rebase public branches
Mechanics of 'git rebase <base>': Moving branch points
Interactive Rebase (git rebase -i): The temporary editor interface
Instruction Keywords: pick, reword, edit, squash, fixup, drop
Conflict Resolution during rebase: --continue vs. --abort
activities: Diagramming session: Visualizing the difference between a merge commit and a rebased linear history
Hands-on Lab: Converting a messy feature branch with 5 small commits into 1 clean 'squashed' commit
Role-play: Fixing a typo in a commit message three positions back using 'reword'
Break-fix scenario: Intentionally creating a rebase conflict and using 'git add' and '--continue' to resolve it
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git. Apress. (Chapter 3.6: Git Branching - Rebasing)
Atlassian Bitbucket Tutorials: 'Merging vs. Rebasing'
The Git Project Documentation: 'A Tutorial Introduction to Git'

lessons.title: Stashing, Tagging, and Ignoring
objectives: Manage workspace clutter with Stashes
Create release milestones with Tags
Filter noise with .gitignore
content_outline: Introduction to Context Switching: The problem of dirty working directories
The Stash Stack: push, pop, apply, and drop commands
Semantic Versioning (SemVer) Principles: MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH logic
Git Tagging: Lightweight vs. Annotated tags for release management
Gitignore Fundamentals: Global vs. Local ignore files
Pattern Matching Syntax: Wildcards, directory markers, and exceptions
activities: Exercise: Saving unfinished work to the stash to fix an urgent bug on a different branch
Tutorial: Creating an annotated release tag 'v1.0.0' and pushing it to a remote
Lab: Configuring a .gitignore file to exclude build artifacts and sensitive OS-generated files
Debugging: Using 'git check-ignore' to troubleshoot why a specific file isn't being tracked
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git. Apress.
Preston-Werner, T. (2013). Semantic Versioning 2.0.0.
Atlassian Bitbucket Tutorials: Git Stash and Git Tag.

lessons.title: Capstone: The Contributor's Workflow
objectives: Integrate all skills into a Pull Request workflow
Perform a peer code review
Audit repository history
content_outline: Open source contribution ethics: Stewardship, communication, and licensing
The complete lifecycle of a contribution: Upstream sync to merge
Code Review Best Practices: Constructive feedback and technical validation
Advanced History Auditing: Using git log, git show, and git blame for auditing
Troubleshooting: Resolving detached HEAD states and common PR merge conflicts
activities: Forking and Branching: Each student forks the capstone repository and creates a feature branch following naming conventions
The PR Submission: Students push their changes and open a formal Pull Request with documented descriptions
Peer Review Rotation: Students are assigned a peer's PR to review, leave comments, and suggest improvements
Historical Audit: Students must use git blame to identify the author of a specific bug in the 'legacy' folder of the project
Conflict Resolution Lab: Instructors push a breaking change to the upstream main to force students to practice 'git rebase' or 'git merge' on their active PRs
resources: Git FAQ and Troubleshooting Guide (Common error codes like 403, 404, and merge conflicts)
citations: Open Source Guides. (n.g.). How to Contribute to Open Source. GitHub.
Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git. Apress.
Atlassian Bitbucket. (n.d.). The Importance of Code Reviews for Development Teams.

quality_score.feedback: This is an exceptionally well-structured and comprehensive syllabus that effectively balances theory, practical application, and documentation. It demonstrates a clear pedagogical progression from foundational concepts to advanced skills, culminating in a practical capstone project. The syllabus covers all essential Git topics with logical sequencing and clear learning objectives.
issues: Missing explicit assessment criteria, grading rubrics, or assignment descriptions for the final project.
No information about course duration, pacing (e.g., hours per lesson), or delivery format (online, in-person, self-paced).
Lacks specification of required/supplementary materials, textbooks, or software versions.
Missing information about prerequisites (e.g., command-line familiarity) and target audience skill level.

gaps_found: The course jumps from theoretical architecture in Lesson 2 directly to staging and committing in Lesson 3 without a clear transition on setting up Git or basic commands.
Lesson 8 (Advanced Rebase) might be too advanced too soon; there's no clear bridge from basic merging to interactive rebasing.
missing_prerequisites: No initial lesson on installing Git or configuring it (user name, email).
No lesson on basic terminal/command-line navigation (cd, ls, mkdir) for absolute beginners.
No introductory lesson explaining what version control is and why it matters before diving into evolution history.
unclear_concepts: 'Git Architecture: Under the Hood' (Lesson 2) could be overwhelming without first understanding simple Git usage.
'Staging and Committing' (Lesson 3) assumes students already know what these terms mean conceptually.
'Advanced Rebase and Interactive Tools' (Lesson 8) sounds intimidating without prior foundation.
recommendations: Add a 'Lesson 0' on terminal basics and Git installation.
Insert a lesson after Lesson 1 explaining core Git concepts (repository, commit, branch) in simple terms before architecture.
Consider moving 'Advanced Rebase' later or splitting it into two lessons with more gradual progression.
Include a hands-on setup exercise early to build confidence before theory-heavy topics.
